<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 215, 388, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 455, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 352, 828, 368]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 462]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 462, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 590, 509]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 509, 606, 525]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 555]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 587]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 619]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Each computer made in a factory contains 1000 components. On average, 1 in 30 000 of these components is defective. Use a suitable approximate distribution to find the probability that a randomly chosen computer contains at least 1 faulty component.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 152, 92, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
Heights of a certain species of animal are known to be normally distributed with standard deviation \(0.17 \text{m}\). A conservationist wishes to obtain a \(99\%\) confidence interval for the population mean, with total width less than \(0.2 \text{m}\). Find the smallest sample size required.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 183, 920, 201]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 228, 92, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 920, 278]]<|/det|>
Following a change in flight schedules, an airline pilot wished to test whether the mean distance that he flies in a week has changed. He noted the distances, \(x \text{km}\), that he flew in 50 randomly chosen weeks and summarised the results as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 285, 697, 304]]<|/det|>
\[n = 50\qquad \Sigma x = 143 300\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 410 900 000\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 324, 688, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label> Calculate unbiased estimates of the population mean and variance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 324, 920, 343]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 355, 153, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 354, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
In the past, the mean distance that he flew in a week was \(2850\mathrm{km}\). Test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, whether the mean distance has changed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 370, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 416, 94, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 415, 920, 450]]<|/det|>
The number of radioactive particles emitted per 150-minute period by some material has a Poisson distribution with mean 0.7.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 463, 148, 482]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 463, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that at most 2 particles will be emitted during a randomly chosen 10-hour period.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 481, 920, 498]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 509, 153, 527]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 509, 920, 543]]<|/det|>
Find, in minutes, the longest time period for which the probability that no particles are emitted is at least 0.99.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 526, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 571, 94, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
The volume, in \(\mathrm{cm}^3\), of liquid left in a glass by people when they have finished drinking all they want is modelled by the random variable \(X\) with probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 609, 628, 650]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}k(x - 2)^2 & 0\leqslant x\leqslant 2,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 657, 292, 675]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 689, 151, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 688, 292, 707]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{3}{8}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 688, 920, 707]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 721, 153, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 721, 655, 740]]<|/det|>
20% of people leave at least \(d \mathrm{cm}^3\) of liquid in a glass. Find \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 721, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 753, 153, 771]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 753, 248, 771]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{E}(X)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 752, 920, 771]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
At the last election, \(70\%\) of people in Apoli supported the president. Luigi believes that the same proportion support the president now. Maria believes that the proportion who support the president now is \(35\%\) . In order to test who is right, they agree on a hypothesis test, taking Luigi's belief as the null hypothesis. They will ask 6 people from Apoli, chosen at random, and if more than 3 support the president they will accept Luigi's belief.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 166, 154, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 166, 497, 184]]<|/det|>
Calculate the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 198, 153, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 198, 692, 216]]<|/det|>
If Maria's belief is true, calculate the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 198, 920, 216]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 229, 153, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 229, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
In fact 2 of the 6 people say that they support the president. State which error, Type I or Type II, might be made. Explain your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 244, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 291, 92, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
Kieran and Andreas are long-jumpers. They model the lengths, in metres, that they jump by the independent random variables \(K \sim \mathrm{N}(5.64, 0.0576)\) and \(A \sim \mathrm{N}(4.97, 0.0441)\) respectively. They each make a jump and measure the length. Find the probability that

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 348, 153, 365]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 348, 594, 365]]<|/det|>
the sum of the lengths of their jumps is less than \(11 \mathrm{~m}\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 348, 920, 365]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 371, 153, 389]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 371, 579, 389]]<|/det|>
Kieran jumps more than 1.2 times as far as Andreas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 371, 920, 389]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 75, 564, 90]]<|/det|>
